Article.Abstract: The mechanisms by which antigenic peptides bearing a glycosylation site may be processed from viral glycoproteins, post-translationally modified, and presented by major histocompatibility complex class I molecules remain poorly understood. With the aim of exploring these processes, we have dissected the structural and functional properties of the MHC-restricted peptide GP92-101 (CSANNSHHYI) generated from the lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus (LCMV) GP1 glycoprotein. LCMV GP92-101 bears a glycosylation motif -NXS- that is naturally N-glycosylated in the mature viral glycoprotein, displays high affinity for H-2D(b) molecules, and elicits a CD8(+) cytotoxic T lymphocyte response. By analyzing the functional properties of natural and synthetic peptides and by identifying the viral sequence(s) from the pool of naturally occurring peptides, we demonstrated that multiple forms of LCMV GP92-101 were generated from the viral glycoprotein and co-presented at the surface of LCMV-infected cells. They corresponded to non-glycosylated and post-translationally modified sequences (conversion of Asn-95 to Asp or alteration of Cys-92). The glycosylated form, despite its potential immunogenicity, was not detected. These data illustrate that distinct, non-mutually exclusive antigen presentation pathways may occur simultaneously within a cell to generate structurally and functionally different peptides from a single genetically encoded sequence, thus contributing to increasing the diversity of the T cell repertoire.
Article.ArticleTitle: Genetically encoded and post-translationally modified forms of a major histocompatibility complex class I-restricted antigen bearing a glycosylation motif are independently processed and co-presented to cytotoxic T lymphocytes.
Article.Affiliations: Institut de Pharmacologie et de Biologie Structurale, UPR 9062 CNRS, 205 route de Narbonne, 31400 Toulouse, France. hudrisie@ipbs.fr.
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Animals; Antigen Presentation(genetics; immunology); Cells, Cultured; Glycosylation; Histocompatibility Antigens Class I(genetics; immunology); Mice; Mice, Inbred C57BL; Protein Processing, Post-Translational(genetics; immunology); T-Lymphocytes, Cytotoxic(immunology)

Epitope.EpitopeComments: Genetically encoded sequence for this subdominant epitope, which is N-glycosylated in the mature glycoprotein at N95 residue in the glycosylation motif NX(S/T).

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: 1 dose of 50-100 μg mixed with 5 μg P30 T helper epitope from tetanus toxoid.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: One week after immunization, lymph node cells were stimulated in vitro for 2 weeks. CTL were restimulated weekly with irradiated C57BL/6 splenocytes and irradiated epitope-pulsed (1 mM) RMA cells in the presence of 30 UI/ml IL2.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Peptide-pulsed target cells are efficiently lysed by CTLs from peptide immunized animals. Target cells pulsed with the D95 (deamidated) modified analog are even more efficiently lysed, showing that these CTLs cross-react with this form of the epitope. The reactivity toward cells pulsed with the glycosylated form is lower, even though MHC binding is similar, showing that glycosylation may affect TCR recognition.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: 1 dose of 50-100 μg mixed with 5 μg P30 T helper epitope from tetanus toxoid.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: One week after immunization, lymph node cells were stimulated in vitro for 2 weeks. CTL were restimulated weekly with irradiated C57BL/6 splenocytes and irradiated epitope-pulsed (1 mM) RMA cells in the presence of 30 UI/ml IL2.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Virus infected target cells are efficiently lysed by CTLs from peptide immunized animals, demonstrating that this epitope is naturally presented at the surface of LCMV-infected cells.

MhcAllele.MhcEvidenceCode: Inferred by motif or alleles present

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The CTL line obtained after peptide immunization is stimulated by the HPLC fractions of the material eluted from virus infected cells that correspond to the epitopic peptide, as well as by the fraction corresponding to the deaminated (D95) form, further demonstrating natural presentation of those epitopes upon infection and the cross-reactivity of the CTLs raised against this epitope. A third fraction, putatively the oxidized form of C92, was also obtained from these cells and may be the result of antigen processing or an artifact from storage of peptide eluates.
A similar binding affinity is seen for the genetically encoded, glycosylated and deaminated forms of this epitope.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: Analog of the genetically encoded sequence for this subdominant epitope, which is N-glycosylated in the mature glycoprotein at N95 residue in the glycosylation motif NX(S/T). An artificial peptide, with the sequence CSADNSHHYI as a N95D deaminated analog is used (as in vivo the de-N-glycosylation by cytoplasmic N-glycanases also deaminates residue N95 to a D residue in its place) to analyze the effect of deglycosylation/deamidation on MHC binding and CTL recognition.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: 1 dose of 50-100 μg mixed with 5 μg P30 T helper epitope from tetanus toxoid.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: One week after immunization, lymph node cells were stimulated in vitro for 2 weeks. CTL were restimulated weekly with irradiated C57BL/6 splenocytes and irradiated epitope-pulsed (1 mM) RMA cells in the presence of 30 UI/ml IL2.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Virus infected target cells are efficiently lysed by CTLs from peptide immunized animals, demonstrating that this epitope is naturally presented at the surface of LCMV-infected cells.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: 1 dose of 50-100 μg mixed with 5 μg P30 T helper epitope from tetanus toxoid.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: One week after immunization, lymph node cells were stimulated in vitro for 2 weeks. CTL were restimulated weekly with irradiated C57BL/6 splenocytes and irradiated epitope-pulsed (1 mM) RMA cells in the presence of 30 UI/ml IL2.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CTLs from peptide immunized animals efficiently lyse peptide-pulsed target cells, but fail to lyse target cells pulsed with N95 (unglycosylated form) and (GlcNac)-N95 (glycosylated form), showing that these CTLs are specific for the immunizing form of this peptide.

MhcAllele.MhcEvidenceCode: Inferred by motif or alleles present

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The CTL line obtained after peptide immunization is stimulated by the HPLC fractions of the material eluted from virus infected cells that correspond to the epitopic peptide, demonstrating natural presentation of this epitope upon infection and the specificity of the CTL reactivity.
A similar binding affinity is seen for the genetically encoded, glycosylated and deaminated forms of this epitope.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: The N-glycosylated form (at N95 residue in the glycosylation motif NX(S/T) of this subdominant epitope is found in the mature glycoprotein. In this study, an artificial peptide with GlcNac N-glycosylation is used to analyze the effect of glycosylation on presentation and immunogenicity.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: 1 dose of 50-100 μg mixed with 5 μg P30 T helper epitope from tetanus toxoid.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: One week after immunization, lymph node cells were stimulated in vitro for 2 weeks. CTL were restimulated weekly with irradiated C57BL/6 splenocytes and irradiated epitope-pulsed (1 mM) RMA cells in the presence of 30 UI/ml IL2.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: CTLs from peptide immunized animals efficiently lyse peptide-pulsed target cells, but fail to lyse target cells pulsed with N95 (unglycosylated form) and D95 (deaminated form), showing that these CTLs are specific for the immunizing form of this peptide.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: 1 dose of 50-100 μg mixed with 5 μg P30 T helper epitope from tetanus toxoid.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: One week after immunization, lymph node cells were stimulated in vitro for 2 weeks. CTL were restimulated weekly with irradiated C57BL/6 splenocytes and irradiated epitope-pulsed (1 mM) RMA cells in the presence of 30 UI/ml IL2.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Virus infected target cells are not lysed by CTLs from peptide immunized animals, suggesting that the epitope is not naturally presented at the surface of LCMV-infected cells.

MhcAllele.MhcEvidenceCode: Inferred by motif or alleles present

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The CTL line obtained after peptide immunization is not stimulated by the HPLC fractions of the material eluted from virus infected cells, even after treatment of the material with EndoH (in case a longer glycosydic moiety is the cause of this lack of recognition), further demonstrating that this glycosylated form is not naturally presented upon infection.
A similar binding affinity is seen for the genetically encoded, glycosylated and deaminated forms of this epitope.
